article.description: First Kansas. Then Texas. Now Missouri.
article.headline: Buffaloes win 10 in a row at home to tie record
article.linkText: Colorado improves NCAA resume by beating No. 22 Missouri
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- First Kansas. Then Texas. Now Missouri. Colorado's impressive run at home has the Buffaloes eyeing their first trip to the NCAA tournament in six years. Blair Wilson hit six 3-pointers and scored 26 points as Colorado beat Missouri 89-68 Saturday night to tie a school record for consecutive home victories. Colorado (16-9, 6-6 Big 12) has won 10 in a row at home, tying a record set in 1979-80, and four of six overall to keep its NCAA Tournament chances alive. ''I don't care who comes in here, I just don't feel like we're going to lose,'' said Colorado's David Harrison, who overcame a slow start to finish with 15 points and 11 rebounds. The Buffaloes also ended an eight-game losing streak against Missouri (16-7, 7-5; No. 22 ESPN/USA Today) to improve their home record to 12-1 overall and 6-0 in conference. Fans followed Colorado's latest victory by storming the court, pushing and shoving with security guards for a chance to be on television or to hop up and down on the Buffalo logo at center court. ''At home everyone has shown up. We need that same thing on the road,'' said Colorado coach Ricardo Patton, whose team is 5-8 on the road. ''We've just got to find a way to play with the same intensity.'' Rickey Paulding had 22 points and Arthur Anderson 17, but Missouri couldn't overcome poor shooting from the 3-point and free-throw lines. Missouri was 3-for-20 from long range and 11-for-24 on free throws to lose for the third time in eight games. ''The free-throw line hurt us,'' Missouri coach Quin Snyder said. ''If we converted a few of those, it would have given us a lift.'' Missouri trailed 47-35 early in the second half, but went on a 13-3 run to cut the lead to 50-48, capped by Anderson's jump hook in the lane with 13:34 left. The Tigers stayed within four midway through, but Colorado went on a 13-4 run and pushed the lead to 71-58 on two free throws by Michel Morandais with 5:43 left. Paulding followed with a hanging three-point play, but Wilson answered with a 3-pointer from the wing to give the Buffaloes a lead that would stay in double digits. ''When we start rolling, I think we're pretty good,'' said Wilson, who was 6-for-10 from 3-point range. ''We got into a good rhythm.'' Harrison struggled in the first half but came alive to start the second. He opened 0-for-5, including a tough shot in traffic to open the second half, but got himself going with a running scoop shot a minute later. Harrison followed with a three-point play off an offensive rebound, then scored on a tough turnaround in the lane that put the Buffaloes up 56-49 with 13 minutes left. He also capped the victory with a two-handed dunk with 41 seconds left that left the rim shaking for nearly a minute. Missouri's efforts to stop Harrison in the first half worked -- he was 0-for-4 with one point -- but it left others open. Wilson took advantage from the outside, hitting three of five from 3-point range for 15 points in the first half. Stephane Pelle worked the opposite side of the paint from Harrison for 10 points and 14 rebounds -- five offensive. Pelle finished with 18 points and 18 rebounds. ''We have different guys who can step up and hit big shots,'' said Wilson, who added four steals. ''Lately, especially here, I've just felt really good shooting the ball.'' Neither team led by more than four points in the first half until Colorado went on a 10-3 run, capped by Morandais' two free throws with 4:00 left. Missouri made six of its first nine shots, but had just one field goal -- a power move by Johnson -- in a span of six minutes as Colorado built a 40-30 halftime lead. ''In games like this, the margins for error are so small,'' Snyder said. ''I think my team fought. We're just not as mature as we need to be.'' Morandais finished with 17 points, 10 assists and six rebounds. Harrison also blocked two shots to set a school record with 75 this season. Poncho Hodges held the previous record with 73 in 1991-92.
